swapRoutine: // Choose two random holders to swap

loopRoutine: // Create array of orthoganally adjacent colors for the first piece
// Create array of orthoganally adjacent colors for the second piece

thenRoutine: // If the new piece will not be the same as one of the adjacent colors, then swap the pieces.
elseRoutine: // If the new piece will match and adjacent color, then start over. This is done to ensure there are enough valid swaps to make the board appear randomized. This is not true randomnes and does not catch or prevent moves from the same holder or moves of the same color, but the 200 iterations should be enough to give an appearance of randomness.

loopRoutine: // Always start from the same valid board then swap pieces 200 times.

info.name: Paletto
info.attribution:
This is an original game by Dieter Stein. The rules, library image, board layout, and piece design are available under CC BY-NC 4.0.

Layout, design, and coding are by LawDawg96 and those elements are released to the Public Domain under CC0.
info.description: Paletto is a colorful logic game with only a few rules and easy to learn. Who can take all pieces of a color or the very last one?
info.similarAwards:
2012 Deutscher Lernspielpreis Leserpreis der Zeitschrift spielen und lernen Winner
2012 Deutscher Lernspielpreis "6 years and up" Nominee
info.ruleText:
For more information about this game and others by Dieter Stein, go to https://spielstein.com/games/paletto.

Preparation

All 36 playing pieces are placed on the game board such that same-colored pieces are not horizontally or vertically adjacent. 

Figure 1 - One of many possible setups.

Objective

The game is won by the player who either takes all 6 pieces of any color or whoever takes the last piece from the board.

Play

Players take turns. In each turn a player chooses a color, then removes any number of same-colored pieces (not necessarily all) from the board and puts them in front of him.

A piece may be removed from the board if ...
  • there are no adjacent pieces on two sides. At start only the corner pieces may be taken - see figure 2,
  • and all remaining pieces are still connected horizontally and vertically after the move - see figure 3.
Figure 2 - The first player may take one or both black pieces, or the yellow one, or the grey one (five different moves). All other pieces have only one free side or they are surrounded completely and therefore unreachable.
Figure 3 - All marked pieces (✔️) are reachable. The blue piece in the middle (❌) may not be taken: it has two free sides, but it also connects other pieces.
info.helpText:
Players sit in seats. Click the restart button to begin the game. A random player is chosen to start and the pieces are randomly distributed.

Drag and drop the pieces into the colored areas beneath the player's seat.
